core_idea: This document provides a detailed overview of the garnishment process in Alberta, explaining how a creditor can enforce a court judgment to collect money owed by a debtor through third parties such as employers or banks. It outlines the necessary legal steps, forms, and procedures involved, as well as important protections and exemptions for debtors. The key concepts include filing judgments, sending demand letters, issuing writs and garnishee summons, and understanding the rights and limitations of all parties in the garnishment process.
initial_content:
The topics in the Dial-A-Law series provide general information on legal issues within the Province of Alberta. The purpose of this topic is to inform you of your legal rights and responsibilities. This is not legal advice. If you require legal advice, you should contact a lawyer.
This topic discusses the enforcement of a judgment by garnishee. All of the information provided below is current as of July 24, 2020. The garnishment process takes time and is complex; however, it is inexpensive and can be effective.
Garnishment
If a judgment has been given in your favor by the Small Claims Court, the Court of Queen’s Bench or Employment Standards, and it is determined that the other party (the debtor) owes you (the creditor) money, then garnishment can help you collect that money. If the debtor refuses to pay you, or is not able to pay you, garnishment allows you to intercept money which may be going to the debtor from a third party (the garnishee).
Examples of possible garnishees may include banks, or the debtor’s employer. For example, if you have a judgment against a debtor, their employer can serve as the garnishee. This will allow you to use garnishment to divert a portion of the debtor’s pay-check to your own hands before the debtor is paid.
STEP 1 – File and serve the court judgment
At the end of a court hearing, you will receive a court judgment. The judgment can be from the Provincial Court, Civil (also known as Small Claims Court), the Court of Queen’s Bench or Employment Standards. Upon receiving the judgment, make at least three copies and distribute them in the following way;
- File one copy with the Court of Queen’s Bench;
- If you have obtained your judgment from a Provincial Court office that is not located in a Queen’s Bench Judicial Centre, the Clerk’s office will allow you to file your judgement by fax if you pay the required fee in advance.
- Serve one copy on the other party, or parties;
- Keep one copy for your file.
When you file your judgment at the Court of Queen’s Bench, the clerk will stamp all the copies, register the judgment, and provide you with a Court of Queen’s Bench file number.
STEP 2 – Send a Demand Letter
Once you receive the action number, you will then need to send a Demand Letter to the other party (the debtor). A Demand Letter is a letter informing the other party that they owe you money for a specific reason, and requesting that they pay you by a specific date.
In this case, you will note that you have a judgment against the debtor, and request that they pay you the amount provided in the judgment. If the debtor complies with your request and pays you, there is no need to resort to garnishment, and the process stops here.
STEP 3 – File a Writ of Enforcement
If the debtor does not respond to the Demand Letter, then you must file a Writ of Enforcement. The Writ of Enforcement forms are available online at the Alberta Courts website (https://www.albertacourts.ca/qb/areas-of-law/civil/forms). Use the same Court of Queen’s Bench file number on the Writ of Enforcement. This notifies other creditors that you have a claim against the debtor, and that the debtor owes you money.
Use one copy of this Writ of Enforcement as a draft and take it to a Clerk at the Court of Queen’s Bench to be sure it is filled out correctly. Once you know it is correct, make at least four copies of the Writ of Enforcement. File all the copies with the Clerk of the Court of Queen’s Bench. They should be distributed in the following way:
- The Clerk will retain one copy (the others will be returned to you);
- Register one copy at the Personal Property Registry;
- Register one copy at the Land Titles Office (if applicable); and
- Keep one copy for your file.
When you have a judgment against a debtor, you are considered a creditor. Registration at the Personal Property Registry and the Land Titles Office will serve as notice to other creditors that you have a claim against the debtor.
It is also your responsibility to register a Status Report at the Personal Property Registry every two years in order to keep it active. This must be done prior to the Writ of Enforcement expiring. This Status Report will detail the judgment amount that is still owed to you. Importantly, you are also required to register a Status Report whenever you receive payment from the debtor outside of the garnishment process – as this payment will reduce the total amount that the debtor owes you.
STEP 4 – File a Garnishee Summons
A “garnishee” is a third party that would be giving money to the debtor. For example, a garnishee may be an employer, a bank, or other third party. A Garnishee Summons notifies the garnishee that they should pay the amount of the judgment directly to you rather than to the debtor.
A Garnishee Summons form can be found on the Alberta Courts website (https://www.albertacourts.ca/qb/areas-of-law/civil/forms). When filling out the form, provide the same information contained in the judgment, described above. The Garnishee Summons must include the following items:
- A Supporting Affidavit – this Affidavit must be sworn before a Commissioner for Oaths. This can be done at the Office of the Clerk when you file your Garnishee Summons.
- A copy of the search that must be done at the Personal Property Registry to see if other Writs are registered against the debtor and the amount of those other Writs.
- The value of all other registered Writs against the debtor.
- The amount that the debtor owes to you, the creditor.
- Any other costs incurred by you in the course of obtaining this judgment – such as search costs within the Personal Property Registry, or Land Titles Offices.
- A total amount that the debtor owes you – this would be the amount listed in the judgment from step (4), plus the costs of any searches or services noted in step (5).
Use one copy as a rough draft and take it to a Clerk at the Court of Queen’s Bench to ensure that it is filled out properly. Once you know that it is correct, make at least five copies of the Garnishee Summons. File all of the copies with the Court of Queen’s Bench. They should be distributed in the following way:
- The Clerk will retain one copy (the other copies will be returned to you);
- Keep one copy for your file; and
- Three copies are to be served on the garnishee.
STEP 5 – Serve a Garnishee
A $25.00 administration fee must be paid to the garnishee along with the Garnishee Summons at the time of service.
Serving a garnishee with a Garnishee Summons may differ depending on if the garnishee is an individual, or a corporation. For individuals, a Garnishee Summons may be served through personal service, or through recorded mail addressed to the individual’s personal or business address (where applicable). For corporate garnishee’s, the creditor must serve an officer or director of the corporation. Alternatively, one can serve another person with authority within the corporation, or serve the corporation via recorded mail to their registered corporate office.
In most cases, the Garnishee Summons is effective for two years. A Garnishee Summons can be renewed after it expires if necessary. If only a portion of the debt is paid to Court, the garnishee must continue to garnish and pay future amounts to Court for two years or until the debt is satisfied.
Garnishee’s Response
Within 15 days of being served with a Garnishee Summons, a garnishee is required to serve the debtor with a copy of the Garnishee Summons and complete the Certificate of Service on the debtor. They must then forward the money and Certificate of Service to the Clerk of the Court. If the garnishee is unable to serve the debtor, they must inform the Clerk of that.
If the garnishee does not serve the debtor and complete the Certificate of Service, you will also be advised by the Clerk’s office. You will then have to serve a copy of the Garnishee Summons on the debtor either personally, or by recorded mail.
When making payments to the Court, a garnishee must pay the amount of money required by the Garnishee Summons within 5 days following the end of the debtor’s last pay period. If there is no money payable, the garnishee must provide reasons to the Court why money will not be paid. For example, if the garnishee is a bank, there may not be any money available in the debtor’s bank account. Alternatively, if the garnishee is the debtor’s employer, the employer may not have owed money to the debtor on the day that you served the summons.
Payments
When the money is paid to the Court, a Clerk will send out a Proposed Distribution. This sets out the amount to be paid to each creditor. A Proposed Distribution is required by law when there is not enough money to pay all creditors. There is a process available to object to the Proposed Distribution.
Money will first be used to pay any fees, expenses, and costs incurred in setting up the fund. Next, those with statutory entitlements (such as money owed through Worker’s Compensation Benefit or Maintenance) will be paid. Then, the creditor who issued the Garnishee Summons is entitled to the first $2,000.00 collected under the Summons. After that, the balance of the money is then divided amongst all creditors in proportion to the amount they are owed.
If the Garnishee is the Debtor’s Employer
If the garnishee is the debtor’s employer, ensure that a Garnishee’s Worksheet is delivered to the employer along with the Garnishee Summons, which is available at the Clerk’s Office or online (https://www.albertacourts.ca/qb/areas-of-law/civil/forms).
The law recognizes that a creditor is not entitled to seize all of a debtor’s money. Rather, the debtor is entitled to keep a certain amount of their money for living expenses. With that in mind, the Garnishee Summons will outline the various employment earnings exemptions that the debtor may use to retain some of their earnings. If the debtor has no dependents, the first $800.00 of the debtor’s earnings per pay period cannot be seized via garnishment. For every dependent that the debtor has, an additional $200 cannot be seized by the creditor.
The following persons are considered to be dependents;
- Any person identified as a dependent by an Order of the Court;
- Any child of the debtor who is under 18 years of age & lives with the debtor;
- The spouse or adult interdependent partner of the debtor; or
- Any relative of the debtor (or of the debtor’s spouse/adult interdependent partner) who lives with the debtor and depends financially on the debtor because of mental or physical infirmity.
Additionally, any amount which is garnished (after the $800 minimum, plus $200 per dependent) can only be garnished up to 50%. For example, if a given debtor had one minor child and earned an income of $1800 per month, $1000 of that would be protected and the creditor could only garnish 50% of the remaining $800 – working out to $400 per month. The law also notes that in any example (not just the example listed previously), net income exceeding $2400 per month may be garnished in its entirety. Exemptions will also apply for judgments regarding alimony or maintenance.
If the Garnishee is the Debtor’s Bank
Garnishee Summons issued on bank accounts will expire 60 days from the date issued. If a bank account is held jointly with someone else, the Garnishee Summons is only good on the day the Garnishee Summons is served.
The money garnished from a jointly held bank account is only that portion considered to belong to the debtor. This is presumed to be one half of the account balance (unless the other joint holders of the account obtain a Court Order stating that they are entitled to a different amount).

optimizations.final_answer:
In Calgary, to enforce a Small Claims Court judgment, you must follow a multi-step legal process. First, after receiving the court judgment, you need to file and serve copies of it appropriately, including filing one with the Court of Queen’s Bench to register the judgment and obtain a file number [11]. Next, send a Demand Letter to the debtor requesting payment by a specific date; if the debtor pays, enforcement ends here [11].

If the debtor does not pay, you must file a Writ of Enforcement with the Court of Queen’s Bench using the file number from your judgment. This writ notifies other creditors and allows you to register your claim at the Personal Property Registry and Land Titles Office if applicable, which serves as public notice of your claim [11]. You must also file Status Reports every two years to keep the writ active and update it when payments are received [11].

To collect the money, you can file a Garnishee Summons against a third party (such as the debtor’s employer or bank) who owes money to the debtor. The Garnishee Summons requires the garnishee to pay the owed amount directly to you instead of the debtor. This summons must be properly completed, filed, and served on the garnishee, who then has 15 days to notify the debtor and pay the court [11]. If the garnishee is the debtor’s employer, certain exemptions apply, such as protecting the first $800 of the debtor’s earnings per pay period from garnishment to allow for living expenses [11].

Payments collected through garnishment are distributed according to legal priorities, including fees, statutory entitlements, and then to creditors proportionally [11]. The garnishment process can last up to two years and may be renewed if necessary [11].

This enforcement procedure is designed to help creditors collect debts awarded by Small Claims Court judgments efficiently while respecting debtor protections under Alberta law [11]. For forms and detailed instructions, the Alberta Courts website provides necessary documents and guidance [11].

- File one copy with the Court of Queen’s Bench.

- Serve one copy on the debtor (other party).  
- Keep one copy for your records.

This topic explains the garnishment process, a method for enforcing a court judgment to collect money owed by a debtor through third parties such as employers or banks. The information below is current as of July 24, 2020. Although garnishment can be complex and time-consuming, it is generally inexpensive and effective.

## Garnishment Overview

If you have a judgment in your favor from the Small Claims Court, the Court of Queen’s Bench, or Employment Standards, and the debtor refuses or is unable to pay, garnishment allows you to intercept money owed to the debtor from a third party (the garnishee). Common garnishees include banks and employers. For example, if the debtor’s employer is the garnishee, a portion of the debtor’s paycheck can be redirected to you before the debtor receives it.

---

## Step 1 – File and Serve the Court Judgment

After a court hearing, you will receive a judgment from the Provincial Court, Civil (Small Claims Court), Court of Queen’s Bench, or Employment Standards. Make at least three copies of the judgment and distribute them as follows:

- File one copy with the Court of Queen’s Bench.  
- If your judgment is from a Provincial Court office outside a Queen’s Bench Judicial Centre, you may file by fax with the required fee.  
- Serve one copy on the debtor (other party).  
- Keep one copy for your records.

The Court clerk will stamp all copies, register the judgment, and provide you with a Court of Queen’s Bench file number.

---

## Step 2 – Send a Demand Letter

Using the action number, send a Demand Letter to the debtor. This letter informs them of the judgment and requests payment by a specific date. If the debtor pays, the garnishment process ends here.

---

## Step 3 – File a Writ of Enforcement

If the debtor ignores the Demand Letter, file a Writ of Enforcement using forms available on the Alberta Courts website. Use your Court of Queen’s Bench file number on the Writ. This notifies other creditors of your claim.

Before filing, have a Clerk review a draft of the Writ to ensure accuracy. Then make at least four copies and file them as follows:

- Clerk retains one copy.  
- Register one copy at the Personal Property Registry.  
- Register one copy at the Land Titles Office (if applicable).  
- Keep one copy for your file.

You must also file a Status Report at the Personal Property Registry every two years to keep the Writ active and whenever you receive payments outside garnishment, as these reduce the amount owed.

---

## Step 4 – File a Garnishee Summons

A garnishee is a third party who owes money to the debtor, such as an employer or bank. A Garnishee Summons directs the garnishee to pay the judgment amount directly to you.

The Garnishee Summons form is available online. It must include:

- A Supporting Affidavit sworn before a Commissioner for Oaths (can be done at the Clerk’s Office).  
- A copy of the Personal Property Registry search showing other Writs against the debtor.  
- The value of all other registered Writs.  
- The amount owed to you.  
- Any additional costs incurred (e.g., registry search fees).  
- The total amount owed (judgment plus costs).

Have a Clerk review a draft of the Garnishee Summons before filing. Make at least five copies and file them as follows:

- Clerk retains one copy.  
- Keep one copy for your file.  
- Serve three copies on the garnishee.

---

## Step 5 – Serve the Garnishee

A $25 administration fee must be paid to the garnishee when serving the Garnishee Summons.

Service methods vary:

- For individuals: personal service or recorded mail to personal/business address.  
- For corporations: serve an officer, director, authorized person, or send recorded mail to the registered office.

The Garnishee Summons is generally effective for two years and can be renewed. If only part of the debt is paid, the garnishee must continue garnishing for two years or until the debt is fully paid.

---

## Garnishee’s Response

Within 15 days of service, the garnishee must:

- Serve the debtor with a copy of the Garnishee Summons and complete a Certificate of Service.  
- Forward the money and Certificate of Service to the Court Clerk.

If the garnishee cannot serve the debtor, they must inform the Clerk. If the garnishee fails to serve the debtor, you will be notified and must serve the debtor yourself.

Payments must be made to the Court within 5 days after the debtor’s last pay period. If no money is payable, the garnishee must explain why (e.g., no funds in bank account or no wages owed on the day of service).

---

## Payments and Distribution

When the Court receives money, a Proposed Distribution is sent to creditors outlining payment amounts. This occurs when funds are insufficient to pay all creditors.

Payment priority is as follows:

1. Fees, expenses, and costs of setting up the fund.  
2. Statutory entitlements (e.g., Worker’s Compensation, Maintenance).  
3. The creditor who issued the Garnishee Summons receives the first $2,000 collected.  
4. Remaining funds are divided proportionally among all creditors.

---

## If the Garnishee is the Debtor’s Employer

Along with the Garnishee Summons, provide the employer with a Garnishee’s Worksheet (available at the Clerk’s Office or online).

The law protects a portion of the debtor’s earnings for living expenses. Exemptions include:

- The first $800 per pay period is exempt if the debtor has no dependents.  
- An additional $200 per dependent is exempt.

Dependents include:

- Persons identified as dependents by Court Order.  
- Children under 18 living with the debtor.  
- The debtor’s spouse or adult interdependent partner.  
- Relatives living with the debtor who depend financially due to mental or physical infirmity.

Only up to 50% of the debtor’s earnings above the exempt amount can be garnished. For example, a debtor with one child earning $1,800 per month would have $1,000 protected ($800 + $200), and 50% of the remaining $800 ($400) could be garnished. This topic explains the garnishment process, a method for enforcing a court judgment to collect money owed by a debtor through third parties such as employers or banks. The information below is current as of July 24, 2020. Although garnishment can be complex and time-consuming, it is generally inexpensive and effective.

## Garnishment Overview

If you have a judgment in your favor from the Small Claims Court, the Court of Queen’s Bench, or Employment Standards, and the debtor refuses or is unable to pay, garnishment allows you to intercept money owed to the debtor from a third party (the garnishee). Common garnishees include banks and employers. For example, if the debtor’s employer is the garnishee, a portion of the debtor’s paycheck can be redirected to you before the debtor receives it.

---

## Step 1 – File and Serve the Court Judgment

After a court hearing, you will receive a judgment from the Provincial Court, Civil (Small Claims Court), Court of Queen’s Bench, or Employment Standards. Make at least three copies of the judgment and distribute them as follows:

- File one copy with the Court of Queen’s Bench.  
- If your judgment is from a Provincial Court office outside a Queen’s Bench Judicial Centre, you may file by fax with the required fee.  
- Serve one copy on the debtor (other party).  
- Keep one copy for your records.

The Court clerk will stamp all copies, register the judgment, and provide you with a Court of Queen’s Bench file number.

---

## Step 2 – Send a Demand Letter

Using the action number, send a Demand Letter to the debtor. This letter informs them of the judgment and requests payment by a specific date. If the debtor pays, the garnishment process ends here.

---

## Step 3 – File a Writ of Enforcement

If the debtor ignores the Demand Letter, file a Writ of Enforcement using forms available on the Alberta Courts website. Use your Court of Queen’s Bench file number on the Writ. This notifies other creditors of your claim.

Before filing, have a Clerk review a draft of the Writ to ensure accuracy. Then make at least four copies and file them as follows:

- Clerk retains one copy.  
- Register one copy at the Personal Property Registry.  
- Register one copy at the Land Titles Office (if applicable).  
- Keep one copy for your file.

You must also file a Status Report at the Personal Property Registry every two years to keep the Writ active and whenever you receive payments outside garnishment, as these reduce the amount owed.

---

## Step 4 – File a Garnishee Summons

A garnishee is a third party who owes money to the debtor, such as an employer or bank. A Garnishee Summons directs the garnishee to pay the judgment amount directly to you.

The Garnishee Summons form is available online. It must include:

- A Supporting Affidavit sworn before a Commissioner for Oaths (can be done at the Clerk’s Office).  
- A copy of the Personal Property Registry search showing other Writs against the debtor.  
- The value of all other registered Writs.  
- The amount owed to you.  
- Any additional costs incurred (e.g., registry search fees).  
- The total amount owed (judgment plus costs).

Have a Clerk review a draft of the Garnishee Summons before filing. Make at least five copies and file them as follows:

- Clerk retains one copy.  
- Keep one copy for your file.  
- Serve three copies on the garnishee.

---

## Step 5 – Serve the Garnishee

A $25 administration fee must be paid to the garnishee when serving the Garnishee Summons.

Service methods vary:

- For individuals: personal service or recorded mail to personal/business address.  
- For corporations: serve an officer, director, authorized person, or send recorded mail to the registered office.

The Garnishee Summons is generally effective for two years and can be renewed. If only part of the debt is paid, the garnishee must continue garnishing for two years or until the debt is fully paid.

---

## Garnishee’s Response

Within 15 days of service, the garnishee must:

- Serve the debtor with a copy of the Garnishee Summons and complete a Certificate of Service.  
- Forward the money and Certificate of Service to the Court Clerk.

If the garnishee cannot serve the debtor, they must inform the Clerk. If the garnishee fails to serve the debtor, you will be notified and must serve the debtor yourself.

Payments must be made to the Court within 5 days after the debtor’s last pay period. If no money is payable, the garnishee must explain why (e.g., no funds in bank account or no wages owed on the day of service).

---

## Payments and Distribution

When the Court receives money, a Proposed Distribution is sent to creditors outlining payment amounts. This occurs when funds are insufficient to pay all creditors.

Payment priority is as follows:

1. Fees, expenses, and costs of setting up the fund.  
2. Statutory entitlements (e.g., Worker’s Compensation, Maintenance).  
3. The creditor who issued the Garnishee Summons receives the first $2,000 collected.  
4. Remaining funds are divided proportionally among all creditors.

---

## If the Garnishee is the Debtor’s Employer

Along with the Garnishee Summons, provide the employer with a Garnishee’s Worksheet (available at the Clerk’s Office or online).

The law protects a portion of the debtor’s earnings for living expenses. Exemptions include:

- The first $800 per pay period is exempt if the debtor has no dependents.  
- An additional $200 per dependent is exempt.

Dependents include:

- Persons identified as dependents by Court Order.  
- Children under 18 living with the debtor.  
- The debtor’s spouse or adult interdependent partner.  
- Relatives living with the debtor who depend financially due to mental or physical infirmity.

Only up to 50% of the debtor’s earnings above the exempt amount can be garnished. For example, a debtor with one child earning $1,800 per month would have $1,000 protected ($800 + $200), and 50% of the remaining $800 ($400) could be garnished. Net income over $2,400 per month may be garnished in full. Exemptions also apply for alimony or maintenance judgments.

---

## If the Garnishee is the Debtor’s Bank

[Content regarding bank garnishees would continue here.]

- Garnishee Summons issued on bank accounts expire 60 days from the date issued.  
- For jointly held bank accounts, the Garnishee Summons is only valid on the day it is served.  
- Only the debtor’s portion of a joint account (presumed to be half) can be garnished unless a Court Order states otherwise.

- Serve one copy on the debtor (other party).  
- Keep one copy for your records.

Using the action number, send a Demand Letter to the debtor. This letter informs them of the judgment and requests payment by a specific date. If the debtor pays, the garnishment process ends here.

optimizations.query: how does wage garnishment work
optimizations.final_answer:
Wage garnishment is a legal process where a portion of a debtor’s earnings is withheld by their employer or another third party (the garnishee) to pay off a court-ordered debt. Typically, a creditor must first obtain a court judgment against the debtor before initiating garnishment, except in some cases involving federal debts where court orders may not be required [11][10]. 

The process begins with the creditor filing and serving the court judgment to the debtor and relevant authorities. If the debtor does not pay voluntarily, the creditor files a Writ of Enforcement and then a Garnishee Summons, which directs the garnishee (often the employer) to withhold part of the debtor’s wages and send it to the creditor or court [11]. The garnishee must notify the debtor and comply within a specified timeframe, usually making payments within five days after the debtor’s last pay period [11].

Wage garnishment laws protect a portion of the debtor’s income to cover living expenses. For example, in Alberta, the first $800 per pay period is exempt if the debtor has no dependents, with an additional $200 exempt per dependent. Only up to 50% of the debtor’s earnings above the exempt amount can be garnished, and net income above a certain threshold may be garnished in full. Dependents include children under 18, spouses, or relatives financially dependent due to infirmity [11].

If the garnishee is a bank, garnishment applies to the debtor’s portion of the account, and the summons typically expires after 60 days [11]. Wage garnishment cannot be applied if the debtor is unemployed, as there are no wages to garnish, though severance or termination pay may be subject to garnishment as it is earned [8].

Overall, wage garnishment is a structured legal tool to enforce debt repayment by intercepting funds before the debtor receives them, while ensuring basic income protections for the debtor [11][10].

After a court hearing, you will receive a judgment from the Provincial Court, Civil (Small Claims Court), Court of Queen’s Bench, or Employment Standards. Make at least three copies of the judgment and distribute them as follows:

- File one copy with the Court of Queen’s Bench.  
- If your judgment is from a Provincial Court office outside a Queen’s Bench Judicial Centre, you may file by fax with the required fee.  
- Serve one copy on the debtor (other party).  
- Keep one copy for your records.

The Court clerk will stamp all copies, register the judgment, and provide you with a Court of Queen’s Bench file number.

---

## Step 2 – Send a Demand Letter

Using the action number, send a Demand Letter to the debtor. This letter informs them of the judgment and requests payment by a specific date. If the debtor pays, the garnishment process ends here.

If the debtor ignores the Demand Letter, file a Writ of Enforcement using forms available on the Alberta Courts website. Use your Court of Queen’s Bench file number on the Writ. This notifies other creditors of your claim.

- Clerk retains one copy.  
- Register one copy at the Personal Property Registry.  
- Register one copy at the Land Titles Office (if applicable).  
- Keep one copy for your file.

The official court judgment collection process typically involves several key steps to enforce and collect money owed after a court issues a judgment. First, once a judgment is obtained, copies must be filed with the appropriate court and served on the debtor to notify them of the obligation to pay [11]. If the debtor does not voluntarily pay, the creditor can send a demand letter requesting payment by a specific date [11]. 

If payment is not made, the creditor may file a Writ of Enforcement, which registers the judgment with relevant registries and notifies other creditors of the claim [11]. Following this, the creditor can initiate garnishment, a legal process to collect money owed by intercepting funds from third parties who owe money to the debtor, such as employers or banks. This involves filing and serving a Garnishee Summons to the garnishee, who is then required to pay the judgment amount directly to the creditor [11].

The garnishee must respond within a set period, serve the debtor with notice, and remit payments to the court. Garnishment protects a portion of the debtor’s income for living expenses, with specific exemptions based on dependents and income levels, ensuring only a lawful portion of wages or funds is collected [11]. Garnishee Summonses have expiration periods but can be renewed to keep the judgment enforceable indefinitely, typically every seven years [7][11].

For detailed procedures, forms, and legal requirements, official court or government websites such as provincial court sites or clerk of courts pages provide authoritative guidance and resources to assist creditors in enforcing judgments through garnishment and other collection methods [3][11].

The topics in the Dial-A-Law series provide general information on legal issues within the Province of Alberta. The purpose of this topic is to inform you of your legal rights and responsibilities. This is not legal advice. If you require legal advice, you should contact a lawyer.

This topic explains the garnishment process, a method for enforcing a court judgment to collect money owed by a debtor through third parties such as employers or banks. The information below is current as of July 24, 2020. Although garnishment can be complex and time-consuming, it is generally inexpensive and effective.

## Garnishment Overview

If you have a judgment in your favor from the Small Claims Court, the Court of Queen’s Bench, or Employment Standards, and the debtor refuses or is unable to pay, garnishment allows you to intercept money owed to the debtor from a third party (the garnishee). Common garnishees include banks and employers. For example, if the debtor’s employer is the garnishee, a portion of the debtor’s paycheck can be redirected to you before the debtor receives it.

---

## Step 1 – File and Serve the Court Judgment

After a court hearing, you will receive a judgment from the Provincial Court, Civil (Small Claims Court), Court of Queen’s Bench, or Employment Standards. Make at least three copies of the judgment and distribute them as follows:

- File one copy with the Court of Queen’s Bench.  
- If your judgment is from a Provincial Court office outside a Queen’s Bench Judicial Centre, you may file by fax with the required fee.  
- Serve one copy on the debtor (other party).  
- Keep one copy for your records.

The Court clerk will stamp all copies, register the judgment, and provide you with a Court of Queen’s Bench file number.

---

## Step 2 – Send a Demand Letter

Using the action number, send a Demand Letter to the debtor. This letter informs them of the judgment and requests payment by a specific date. If the debtor pays, the garnishment process ends here.

---

## Step 3 – File a Writ of Enforcement

If the debtor ignores the Demand Letter, file a Writ of Enforcement using forms available on the Alberta Courts website. Use your Court of Queen’s Bench file number on the Writ. This notifies other creditors of your claim.

Before filing, have a Clerk review a draft of the Writ to ensure accuracy. Then make at least four copies and file them as follows:

- Clerk retains one copy.  
- Register one copy at the Personal Property Registry.  
- Register one copy at the Land Titles Office (if applicable).  
- Keep one copy for your file.

You must also file a Status Report at the Personal Property Registry every two years to keep the Writ active and whenever you receive payments outside garnishment, as these reduce the amount owed.

---

## Step 4 – File a Garnishee Summons

A garnishee is a third party who owes money to the debtor, such as an employer or bank. A Garnishee Summons directs the garnishee to pay the judgment amount directly to you.

The Garnishee Summons form is available online. It must include:

- A Supporting Affidavit sworn before a Commissioner for Oaths (can be done at the Clerk’s Office).  
- A copy of the Personal Property Registry search showing other Writs against the debtor.  
- The value of all other registered Writs.  
- The amount owed to you.  
- Any additional costs incurred (e.g., registry search fees).  
- The total amount owed (judgment plus costs).

Have a Clerk review a draft of the Garnishee Summons before filing. Make at least five copies and file them as follows:

- Clerk retains one copy.  
- Keep one copy for your file.  
- Serve three copies on the garnishee.

---

## Step 5 – Serve the Garnishee

A $25 administration fee must be paid to the garnishee when serving the Garnishee Summons.

Service methods vary:

- For individuals: personal service or recorded mail to personal/business address.  
- For corporations: serve an officer, director, authorized person, or send recorded mail to the registered office.

The Garnishee Summons is generally effective for two years and can be renewed. If only part of the debt is paid, the garnishee must continue garnishing for two years or until the debt is fully paid.

---

## Garnishee’s Response

Within 15 days of service, the garnishee must:

- Serve the debtor with a copy of the Garnishee Summons and complete a Certificate of Service.  
- Forward the money and Certificate of Service to the Court Clerk.

If the garnishee cannot serve the debtor, they must inform the Clerk. If the garnishee fails to serve the debtor, you will be notified and must serve the debtor yourself.

Payments must be made to the Court within 5 days after the debtor’s last pay period. If no money is payable, the garnishee must explain why (e.g., no funds in bank account or no wages owed on the day of service).

---

## Payments and Distribution

When the Court receives money, a Proposed Distribution is sent to creditors outlining payment amounts. This occurs when funds are insufficient to pay all creditors.

Payment priority is as follows:

1. Fees, expenses, and costs of setting up the fund.  
2. Statutory entitlements (e.g., Worker’s Compensation, Maintenance).  
3. The creditor who issued the Garnishee Summons receives the first $2,000 collected.  
4. Remaining funds are divided proportionally among all creditors.

---

## If the Garnishee is the Debtor’s Employer

Along with the Garnishee Summons, provide the employer with a Garnishee’s Worksheet (available at the Clerk’s Office or online).

The law protects a portion of the debtor’s earnings for living expenses. Exemptions include:

- The first $800 per pay period is exempt if the debtor has no dependents.  
- An additional $200 per dependent is exempt.

Dependents include:

- Persons identified as dependents by Court Order.  
- Children under 18 living with the debtor.  
- The debtor’s spouse or adult interdependent partner.  
- Relatives living with the debtor who depend financially due to mental or physical infirmity.

Only up to 50% of the debtor’s earnings above the exempt amount can be garnished. For example, a debtor with one child earning $1,800 per month would have $1,000 protected ($800 + $200), and 50% of the remaining $800 ($400) could be garnished. Net income over $2,400 per month may be garnished in full. Exemptions also apply for alimony or maintenance judgments.

- Garnishee Summons issued on bank accounts expire 60 days from the date issued.  
- For jointly held bank accounts, the Garnishee Summons is only valid on the day it is served.  
- Only the debtor’s portion of a joint account (presumed to be half) can be garnished unless a Court Order states otherwise.
